I understand that a 10 min video is extremely attractive to learning but I also hope audiences do not walk away thinking they have a good grasp of the content. This video, for example is inaccurate in several ways from how DNA is compared (there's a lot more to what was presented. the usual figure of 1.23% is not accurate, but neither is the 4% he states in the video) to the implicit assumption that behaviour is governed by DNA (the extent to which we are simply not sure of). The presenter speaks of gene expression, i.e. epigenetics, and yet this necessarily involves interaction with the environment. Finally, there are some super important facts missing - humans for example, have 3 times the neurons of chimps. However, the actual explanation of these are lengthy.

Videos like thi provide an excellent starting point, but there are now many free full-length videos explaining thing like human vs chimp differences from MIT, Stanford, and the likes. Consider checking those out too

Claims of only a few percent difference between chimpanzee and human DNA are based on comparing only the genes that they have in common, but there are many genes that are present only in chimps and many other genes that are present only in humans, so these aren't accounted for in such comparisons. It is also incorrect to claim or assume that based on random changes we expect half the differences to have arisen in chimps and half in humans, because chimps evolve much more rapidly than humans. Chimps' differences from our last common ancestor are substantially greater than humans' differences. This is because evolution happens when mutations occur in the germ line, each time that an egg is fertilized by a sperm and an offspring is produced --- some estimates reckon that about 600 new mutations occur in each new human conceptus. Since the chimp generation time is much shorter than the human generation time, that is chimps reach sexual maturity much faster than humans, they have gone through many more generations since our last common ancestor, hence chimps are much more highly evolved than humans. Note that high evolution rate has nothing to do with being more advanced or superior in any way, since mutation and evolution is a random walk in no particular direction. If a new mutation is advantageous it may nevertheless be lost by chance, and even if is inherited by descendants it takes many generations to spread to a substantial proportion of the species. Even a new mutation that is present in thousands of individuals can be lost by chance (genetic drift).

All the same ingredients. It is both order of operations and the combination of ingredients that makes the difference.
A small difference like boiling the toast, or toasting the eggs, will make a major difference to the product.
Thus, percentage differences in DNA commonality have small explanatory power.
